questions.text:
A 30-year-old female presents with painful vesicular lesions on the external genitalia. She reports recurrent episodes of similar lesions. Tzanck smear shows multinucleated giant cells.
What is the most likely causative virus?
questions.solution:
• Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) is the causative agent behind genital herpes, which is characterized by painful vesicular lesions that can recur multiple times. The two types of HSV are HSV-1, which typically affects the orolabial region, and HSV-2, which is more often responsible for genital herpes.
  • In this case, the presence of vesicular lesions on the genitalia and a history of recurrence points towards HSV-2 as the likely cause. HSV establishes latency in the dorsal root ganglia, leading to episodes of reactivation, often triggered by stress, illness, or immunosuppression.
  • The Tzanck smear shows multinucleated giant cells, which are characteristic of herpesvirus infections, including both HSV and VZV. The multinucleated cells are formed due to the fusion of infected cells, and this finding helps in diagnosing herpes infections.

Differential Diagnosis:

Option A: Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV) is associated with infectious mononucleosis and some lymphoproliferative disorders.

Option B: Cytomegalovirus (CMV) can cause congenital infections and severe illness in immunocompromised patients but does not typically cause painful genital lesions.

Option D: Varicella Zoster Virus (VZV) causes chickenpox and shingles but does not typically cause recurrent genital lesions.

Key Takeaways:

  • HSV-2 is the most common cause of recurrent painful genital lesions.
  • Multinucleated giant cells on a Tzanck smear are diagnostic of herpesvirus infections.
  • HSV establishes latency in the sensory ganglia, leading to recurrent outbreaks.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old male presents with a painful rash distributed along the thoracic dermatomes. The patient had chickenpox during childhood. On examination, grouped vesicles are seen over the left side of his chest.
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Varicella Zoster Virus (VZV) causes two main diseases: chickenpox (primary infection) and shingles (reactivation of latent VZV).
  • After an initial chickenpox infection, VZV becomes latent in the dorsal root ganglia and can reactivate later in life as shingles, particularly in older adults or immunocompromised patients.
  • The presentation of painful grouped vesicles distributed along a single dermatome (thoracic in this case) is characteristic of herpes zoster (shingles). The dermatomal pattern reflects the reactivation of the virus from a specific ganglion, leading to localized pain and vesicular rash.
  • The patient's history of chickenpox during childhood indicates prior exposure to VZV, making reactivation (shingles) the most likely diagnosis.

Other options:

Option B: Primary Varicella (chickenpox) would present with a generalized vesicular rash, not restricted to a dermatome.

Option C: Herpes Simplex could cause painful vesicular lesions but typically involves the oral or genital regions rather than a dermatomal distribution.

Option D: Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease is caused by Coxsackievirus and presents with vesicles on the hands, feet, and mouth, not along a dermatome.

Key Takeaways:

  • Shingles (Herpes Zoster) is a reactivation of VZV that manifests as a painful vesicular rash limited to a dermatome.
  • Reactivation of VZV is more common in older adults and immunocompromised individuals.
  • The dermatomal pattern and vesicular rash are key clues for diagnosing shingles.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old male presents with fever, sore throat, lymphadenopathy, and splenomegaly. His monospot test is positive, and peripheral blood smear shows atypical lymphocytes.
Which virus is responsible for this presentation?
questions.solution:
• Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV) is a member of the Herpesviridae family and is the primary cause of infectious mononucleosis (IM). The virus infects B lymphocytes and leads to the characteristic symptoms of fever, pharyngitis, cervical lymphadenopathy, and splenomegaly.
  • A positive Monospot test (heterophile antibody test) is diagnostic for EBV-induced infectious mononucleosis, and the presence of atypical lymphocytes (reactive CD8+ T cells) on peripheral blood smear further supports the diagnosis.
  • EBV is also associated with various lymphoproliferative disorders and malignancies, including Burkitt's lymphoma and nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

Other options:

Option A: Cytomegalovirus (CMV) can cause a mononucleosis-like syndrome but is typically Monospot-negative.

Option C: Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) causes orolabial and genital lesions but does not cause infectious mononucleosis.

Option D:Human Papillomavirus (HPV) is linked to warts and cancers (e.g., cervical cancer) but not infectious mononucleosis.

Key Takeaways:

  • Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV) causes infectious mononucleosis, presenting with fever, pharyngitis, lymphadenopathy, and splenomegaly.
  • A positive Monospot test and atypical lymphocytes are diagnostic features of EBV infection.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old female presents for routine cervical screening. A Pap smear shows koilocytotic cells. She has no symptoms, but her sexual history reveals multiple partners.
What is the most likely causative virus associated with these findings?
questions.solution:
• Human Papillomavirus (HPV) is a DNA virus that is primarily transmitted through sexual contact. Certain strains of HPV, particularly types 16 and 18, are high-risk and strongly associated with the development of cervical cancer.
  • The koilocytes observed on Pap smear are hallmark cells of HPV infection. Koilocytes are squamous epithelial cells with enlarged, irregular nuclei and perinuclear halos.
  • HPV infection can lead to cervical dysplasia and is often asymptomatic. This is why routine cervical screening (Pap smears) is essential for early detection of HPV-related changes that may progress to cervical cancer.

Other options:

Option A: Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is associated with congenital infections and immunocompromised states, but not cervical dysplasia or cancer.

Option C: Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) causes vesicular lesions but does not cause koilocytosis.

Option D: Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV) is linked to infectious mononucleosis and lymphomas, not cervical cancer.

Key Takeaways:

  • HPV infection, particularly with high-risk strains (e.g., HPV 16, 18), is associated with cervical dysplasia and cervical cancer.
  • Koilocytes on Pap smear are indicative of HPV infection.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old male with a history of intravenous drug use presents with jaundice, abdominal pain, and elevated liver enzymes. Serology shows the presence of HBsAg and HBeAg.
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Hepatitis B Virus (HBV) is a DNA virus that primarily infects the liver, causing both acute and chronic hepatitis. The presence of HBsAg (Hepatitis B surface antigen) in the blood indicates an active HBV infection, and HBeAg suggests viral replication and high infectivity.
  • Intravenous drug use is a significant risk factor for HBV transmission, as the virus is spread through blood and body fluids. In the acute phase, patients may present with jaundice, abdominal pain, and elevated liver enzymes (ALT, AST).
  • Chronic Hepatitis B can lead to complications such as cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC).

Other options:

Option A: Hepatitis A is transmitted via the fecal-oral route and does not lead to chronic infection.

Option B: Hepatitis C is transmitted via blood, often associated with intravenous drug use, but its diagnosis is confirmed by anti-HCV antibodies and HCV RNA, not HBsAg.

Option D: Hepatitis E is transmitted through contaminated water and typically causes acute hepatitis, primarily in endemic areas.

Key Takeaways:

  • HBsAg and HBeAg indicate an active Hepatitis B infection with high infectivity.
  • Hepatitis B is a significant cause of chronic liver disease, particularly in individuals with risk factors such as intravenous drug use.

questions.text:
Match the DNA Virus with its Associated Disease or Condition:
1. Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV)
2. Cytomegalovirus (CMV)
3. Human Papillomavirus (HPV)
4. Hepatitis B Virus (HBV)
5. Varicella Zoster Virus (VZV)
Options:
a. Cervical cancer
b. Infectious mononucleosis
c. Congenital infections
d. Shingles
e. Chronic liver disease
questions.solution:
1. Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV) causes infectious mononucleosis, characterized by fever, pharyngitis, and lymphadenopathy.
  2. Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is a major cause of congenital infections, leading to serious complications such as hearing loss and developmental delays.
  3. Human Papillomavirus (HPV), particularly types 16 and 18, is strongly associated with cervical cancer.
  4. Hepatitis B Virus (HBV) causes chronic liver disease, including cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma.
  5. Varicella Zoster Virus (VZV) causes shingles when reactivated from its latent form in the dorsal root ganglia.

Key Takeaways:

  • DNA viruses are linked to various diseases, including cervical cancer, congenital infections, chronic liver disease, and shingles.

choices.text: Genetic reassortment between human and animal influenza viruses
Rapid mutations in the viral hemagglutinin and neuraminidase proteins
The presence of antigenically stable viral strains

questions.text:
A 34-year-old male presents with sudden onset of fever, myalgia, cough, and fatigue. He reports no recent travel. Nasopharyngeal swab confirms a diagnosis of influenza. The patient asks why he needs to be vaccinated every year.
What is the primary reason for the need for annual influenza vaccination?
questions.solution:
1. Influenza virus is an RNA virus belonging to the Orthomyxoviridae family. The virus exhibits antigenic drift, which involves frequent mutations in the genes encoding the hemagglutinin (HA) and neuraminidase (NA) proteins, leading to minor changes in the viral surface proteins. This results in the need for annual vaccination because the immune system’s previous response may not recognize the new viral strain.
  2. Antigenic shift, which is the genetic reassortment between human and animal strains, can result in pandemics but is less frequent than antigenic drift.

Option A. Genetic reassortment (antigenic shift) occurs but is not the reason for annual vaccination. It is more associated with pandemics.

Option C. Antigenically stable strains would not require frequent vaccination.

Option D. Cross-reactivity between strains from previous vaccinations is insufficient to prevent infection due to antigenic drift.

Key Takeaways:

  • Antigenic drift is responsible for the need for annual influenza vaccination.
  • Both hemagglutinin and neuraminidase proteins mutate frequently, allowing the virus to evade the immune system.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old male presents with weight loss, chronic diarrhea, and night sweats. He is a truck driver over the past few years. His test reveals

Which virus is most likely responsible for the patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
1. Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) is an RNA retrovirus from the Retroviridae family. It infects and depletes CD4+ T cells, leading to immunosuppression and the development of Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome (AIDS) when the CD4 count falls below 200 cells/µL.
  2. Clinical symptoms: Chronic diarrhea, weight loss, and night sweats are common in advanced HIV/AIDS, along with opportunistic infections due to immunosuppression.

Option A. Hepatitis C Virus (HCV) primarily causes liver disease, not immunosuppression or opportunistic infections.

Option C. Influenza Virus causes acute respiratory illness but does not lead to immunosuppression.

Option D. Dengue Virus causes fever, rash, and hemorrhagic symptoms but not the chronic symptoms seen in this case.

Key Takeaways: HIV is a retrovirus that causes progressive immunosuppression by depleting CD4+ T cells, leading to AIDS.

CD4 count of <200 cells/µL and opportunistic infections are defining features of AIDS.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old female presents with high fever, severe muscle and joint pain, and a maculopapular rash. She recently returned from a trip to Southeast Asia. Laboratory findings show leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, and elevated liver enzymes.
Which viral infection is most likely responsible for her symptoms?
questions.solution:
1. Dengue Virus is an RNA virus from the Flaviviridae family, transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes. It causes Dengue Fever, characterized by high fever, severe muscle and joint pain (breakbone fever), and a maculopapular rash. Laboratory findings typically show leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, and sometimes elevated liver enzymes.
  2. The patient’s recent travel to an endemic area (Southeast Asia) supports the diagnosis, as Dengue is prevalent in tropical and subtropical regions.

Other options:

Option A. Zika Virus causes milder symptoms with rash and is more associated with congenital infections.

Option C. Chikungunya Virus also causes fever and joint pain but is less likely to present with severe muscle pain and thrombocytopenia.

Option D. Yellow Fever Virus causes hepatitis, fever, and jaundice but not the classic muscle and joint pain seen with Dengue.

Key Takeaways:

  • Dengue Virus causes Dengue Fever, characterized by fever, muscle and joint pain, rash, and cytopenias.
  • It is transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes in tropical regions.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after being bitten by a bat. He reports pain and tingling at the site of the bite. He also exhibits agitation and hydrophobia.
Which virus is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.solution:
1. Rabies Virus is an RNA virus from the Rhabdoviridae family and is primarily transmitted through the bite of an infected animal (e.g., dogs, bats). The virus travels from the site of the bite to the central nervous system (CNS) via retrograde axonal transport, causing encephalitis.
  2. Hydrophobia (fear of water) is a classic sign of rabies due to pharyngeal muscle spasms triggered by swallowing. Other symptoms include agitation, confusion, and progressive paralysis.

Other options:

Option B. Lassa Virus causes hemorrhagic fever and is transmitted by rodents, not through animal bites.

Option C. West Nile Virus is transmitted by mosquitoes and causes fever, rash, and encephalitis but is not associated with hydrophobia.

Option D. Japanese Encephalitis Virus is mosquito-borne and causes encephalitis but does not have the specific association with animal bites and hydrophobia.

Key Takeaways:

  • Rabies Virus causes a fatal encephalitis characterized by hydrophobia, agitation, and paralysis.
  • It is transmitted through the bite of infected animals, with early post-exposure prophylaxis being crucial for survival.

questions.text:
A 2-year-old child presents with profuse watery diarrhea, vomiting, and dehydration. The child attends daycare, and several other children have had similar symptoms recently.
Which virus is most likely responsible for this child's illness?
questions.solution:
1. Rotavirus is an RNA virus from the Reoviridae family and is a leading cause of severe diarrhea in infants and young children worldwide, particularly in daycare settings. It causes profuse watery diarrhea, vomiting, and dehydration, leading to high rates of hospitalization in children.
  2. Rotavirus is spread via the fecal-oral route and can cause outbreaks in daycare centers. Vaccination has significantly reduced the incidence of severe cases.

Other options:

Option A. Norovirus also causes viral gastroenteritis but is more common in adults and older children.

Option B. Adenovirus can cause diarrhea but is not as common or severe in young children.

Option D. Astrovirus causes milder diarrhea and is less common than Rotavirus.

Key Takeaways:

  • Rotavirus is a common cause of severe diarrhea in young children and is associated with outbreaks in daycare settings.
  • Vaccination has reduced the severity of infections but does not eliminate all cases.

questions.text:
A 5-year-old boy presents with fever, cough, conjunctivitis, and rash that started on the face and spread downward.


What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
1. Measles Virus is an RNA virus from the Paramyxoviridae family and causes measles (rubeola). The classic prodrome includes fever, cough, conjunctivitis, and coryza. The maculopapular rash typically starts on the face and spreads caudally.
  2. Koplik spots, which are small white spots on the buccal mucosa, are pathognomonic for measles and appear before the rash.

Other options:

Option B. Rubella Virus causes a milder rash and does not present with Koplik spots.

Option C. Parvovirus B19 causes erythema infectiosum (fifth disease), with a slapped-cheek rash.

Option D. Coxsackievirus causes hand, foot, and mouth disease, presenting with vesicles on the hands, feet, and mouth.

Key Takeaways:

  • Measles Virus causes a maculopapular rash that spreads from the face downward, accompanied by Koplik spots on the buccal mucosa.
  • The prodrome includes cough, coryza, and conjunctivitis.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old male presents with fever, chills, and malaise after returning from a trip to sub-Saharan Africa. A blood smear is shown,

Which species of Plasmodium is most likely responsible for this infection?
questions.solution:
1. The blood smear shows the typical "ring form" trophozoites of Plasmodium falciparum inside red blood cells. The presence of multiple rings within a single red blood cell is highly suggestive of P. falciparum, a feature not typically seen in other species of Plasmodium.
  1. Plasmodium vivax and P. ovale show enlarged red blood cells with Schüffner’s dots, and Plasmodium malariae does not typically show multiple rings per RBC.
  1. Plasmodium falciparum is the most dangerous species of malaria and is commonly found in sub-Saharan Africa, making it the most likely cause in this patient who has returned from that region.

Key Takeaways:

  • Plasmodium falciparum often shows multiple rings per RBC.
  • It is the most virulent form of malaria, leading to severe complications such as cerebral malaria.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman presents with painless, enlarging skin ulcers after a trip to South America. A biopsy of the ulcer shows FOLLOWING FINDINGS seen in macrophages (see image).

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
1. The biopsy shows intracellular amastigotes, a diagnostic feature of Leishmania species, particularly in cutaneous leishmaniasis.
  1. The patient’s travel history to South America and the presence of painless skin ulcers further support the diagnosis of cutaneous leishmaniasis caused by Leishmania spp.
  2. Mucocutaneous leishmaniasis can present with more destructive lesions involving mucosal tissues, whereas visceral leishmaniasis affects internal organs like the spleen and liver, not the skin.

Key Takeaways:

  • Cutaneous leishmaniasis presents with painless, enlarging ulcers and intracellular amastigotes on biopsy.
  • The patient's travel history is important for narrowing down the species.

questions.text:
A 34-year-old male with HIV presents with fever, headache, and confusion. A contrast-enhanced CT scan of the brain reveals the following (see image).

What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
1. In immunocompromised patients, particularly those with HIV/AIDS, multiple ring-enhancing lesions on brain CT are strongly indicative of cerebral toxoplasmosis caused by Toxoplasma gondii.

Option B: Naegleria fowleri causes primary amebic meningoencephalitis, which typically presents differently, without the characteristic ring-enhancing lesions.

Option C: Plasmodium falciparum can cause cerebral malaria, but it does not present with ring-enhancing lesions on brain imaging.

Option D: Entamoeba histolytica is associated with liver abscesses rather than brain lesions.

Key Takeaways:

  • Cerebral toxoplasmosis presents with multiple ring-enhancing lesions in patients with immunocompromised states, particularly HIV.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old male with a history of recent travel to India presents with bloody diarrhea. A colonoscopy shows x in the large intestine (see image).

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Flask-shaped ulcers in the colon are pathognomonic for intestinal amebiasis, which is caused by Entamoeba histolytica. This finding is a hallmark of the invasive form of the disease.

Option A: Ulcerative colitis is inflammatory bowel disease, , presenting with red erythematous mucosa, pseudopolyps etc.

Option B: Crohn’s disease is inflammatory bowel diseases, presenting with fissures, strictures , non caseating granuloma but do not typically present with flask-shaped ulcers.

Option D: Giardiasis affects the small intestine and causes non-bloody diarrhea, malabsorption and greasy stools not flask-shaped ulcers in the large intestine.

Key Takeaways:

  • Flask-shaped ulcers in the colon are highly specific for amebiasis caused by Entamoeba histolytica.
  • Travel history to endemic areas (e.g., India) is important in diagnosing amebiasis.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old male presents with fever, weight loss, and swelling around the eyes after a trip to Central America. A blood smear shows a flagellated protozoan with an undulating membrane (see image).

What is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
1. The blood smear shows the trypomastigote form of Trypanosoma cruzi, characterized by a flagellated protozoan with an undulating membrane, which is the causative agent of Chagas disease.
  2. The patient's travel history to Central America is consistent with Chagas disease, which is transmitted by the reduviid bug (kissing bug).

Incorrect Options : Trypanosoma brucei causes African sleeping sickness, and Leishmania donovani causes visceral leishmaniasis, while Plasmodium vivax is a cause of malaria, none of which are consistent with this patient’s clinical presentation.

Key Takeaways:

  • Trypanosoma cruzi causes Chagas disease, presenting with fever, weight loss, and characteristic Romana’s sign (periorbital swelling).
  • Travel history is essential in differentiating between Trypanosoma species.
